utterances.utterance: Look at the baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Speaking of pests, Dana is back sitting on a stack of dog pictures which is probably good for her since this morning she had her first colonoscopy, a milestone in one's life, it's kind of like your first date in that before both you are covered with sweat and paralyzed by explosive diarrhea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We are making that public?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I should have asked. I should have asked. My fault. But wait. But we're so glad you made it here anyway. Since we left the table, I've lost 30 pounds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't just get my hunch removed. I just decided to exercise more. No. Before I was a strong seven but now, I am an irresistible 9.3. No wonder this happens. Check that out. A proposal, a proposal on Friday night, can you blame him? I'd marry myself if that wasn't illegal. That's in Detroit where everything is legal. But if you told us 15 months ago that this how long it would take to return, we all would've laughed at you. But if Jeffrey Toobin can come back, why can't we? But we hope you are as happy to see us here as we are as happy to see each other and if you are not, just like your germs, keep them to yourself. I have to commend you, Dana, after I applied the peer pressure, you had a fairly invasive procedure this morning and yet you showed up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's happened. So, when we first started THE FIVE, I was 10 years away -- well, actually, yes, 11 years away from needing a colonoscopy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's all I know. Yes, OK. So, America, yes, that's what I did this morning. And I wasn't sure we would talk about that. But since we are, everybody should get their checks, they just changed it to 45.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They lowered it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Which is why I had to go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I had to go back in time and get a retroactive colonoscopy which often like watching CNN.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that's great because you get to go to sleep for like 25 minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the best.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's like the best sleep you ever had.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the best just getting knocked out. So, Jesse, you are kind of like now part of the family. It took -- it took a few mistakes and writing a book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I love being back at the table because I have something to prop my book up on. There it is, hard copy. Greg, was it a man that propose to you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. I just want to make sure the audience knows that, that was a guy. I do like being back at the table because I'm tall again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You guys are now short.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm so short.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We couldn't see that in the boxes so that makes me feel better. I can also get a little whiff of Richard's cologne, what is that, Tom Ford, Richard?

utterances.speaker: RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to tell you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. I can read Dana's body language when I cross the line.

utterances.speaker: PERNO
utterances.utterance: I can hold your hand.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can hold my hand again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Now we're back safe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Again, we can consensually touch each other. Greg has to listen to me. He can't bury his face in his own notes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Dagen can't wear track pants. I don't know why that's important to me but it's very important.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: You commented on that a lot during COVID. You've seen me like, are you going to get dressed when you come to work? It was the track pants or shorts is to wear.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, it's important that we are all here because now we can -- it's also the cues that you get from people's faces that you are missing when we are on, in the vans so we end up talking over it -- well we can't help it because there was a tape delay. But we end up not knowing when to shut up like I'm doing now.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Well, even in the socially distanced stools that we were sitting on I am legally blind.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: So, I couldn't even see you then, Jesse could have been knitting booties for junior or you could have been dressed up like Yosemite Sam and I wouldn't have known it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: You are so far away which we know you only you on the weekends.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is true. The CHAPS. Richard, what are you -- are you excited to be back on our first day?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I am excited to be back on your first day,Â congratulations, back at the table. And I commend you on the weight loss, I mean, you know, like every -- like most Americans I gained the COVID 30, but I've dropped the COVID 30 as well, thanks to a personal trainer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I had the choice, you go in one direction which is eating and drinking into oblivion or not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I chose the not. So.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's great. I mean, there's been a lot. It was funny I was thinking about how we sat here and said OK, well, see you in two weeks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Flatten the curve.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like it was going to flatten the curve, we'll see you in two weeks. At most, three --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and it really was a really long year for a lot of people. And now people are making this decision to come back to work or not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would just say that if you are hesitating, and I get it. Like there might be a lot of reasons, I do think that the first like, 24 hours back in the office feels weird and then you're like right back in the saddle and it's great to be around people again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Especially at a rodeo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wonder if they say that at the Rodeo. This is not my first day on the job.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not my first day in the office.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They don't say this is not my first rodeo. Here's a good question I just thought of. If this happened again next year, what would we do differently? I'm going to say no lockdowns.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think you'd isolate the elderly and the sick and the rest of the country could maybe go about their business in a safe, clean way. Maybe you'd learn that. People are still wearing masks, though, I saw someone on the beach wearing a mask and I didn't want to reverse mask shame her --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- because she was renting the house next to me and that would have been awkward but also, watching the NBA playoffs this weekend, you see these guys they're sweating all over each other, they're boxing each other, they're in each other's face talking trash and then they go to the bench, they have to sit 6 feet separate and wear a mask. I mean, what -- does the commissioner know something we don't know, that's the dumbest thing I've ever heard. So, I think a lot of this is still superstition.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, it's like we have -- we need probably more consistency and guidance. But I -- what did -- do we have any proof that the lockdowns actually helped? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know that we do, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I think that a lot of it, like the after-action report as it's called has yet to be -- like, maybe it helped in some ways, right? So, we know that sometimes in super crowded areas, you could get that if people weren't masked and at the beginning that was happening but we did know pretty early on that schools were not a place of transmission.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We knew that planes were not a place of transmission. Do you know that I believe this has held up, there's not a single case of a patient to a dentist or a dentist to a patient getting COVID. And you had -- think of how many dentist's office had to shut down with all those months.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And colonoscopy offices too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, eight weeks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Eight weeks.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I got my colonoscopy my first went too during the -- during the last year, like last November and just thinking about the prep makes me --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- (Inaudible) a little bit. What --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The key is not to eat for two days.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: But I'm still -- I'm still 20 pounds heavier even with the cleanup. One thing about the upside though for the lockdowns, just quick, was that productivity soared at some companies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Like at --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the conundrum, right?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Like technology companies because people were working more hours because they were working the hours --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not commuting.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- not to commute.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And now these businesses want them back in New York and what they're going to have are fractious, angry employees who don't do anything.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Do less work.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, we learned that commuting is the worst thing you may not need any more, that you need consistency, that putting people in with their elder it was a bad idea. Children should be at school. I mean, we actually for the -- this was a good practice run even though a lot of people didn't make it through.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And I think -- I think we also learned that if you are sick, stay home. I think people were like, I mean, before you would take a rest --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- I have a fever, I'm going to run into the pharmacy to get some pills.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Now you're like, actually, I'm not going to go to the pharmacy, I'm going to stay home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And that's a good thing, that's a way to be kind to your neighbors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is true. All right. Coming up, President Biden and allies calling for a COVID investigation but are they playing right into China's hands?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not Elton John.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: President Biden and top allies are promising a crackdown in China over COVID, but is it already doomed to fail? The G7 putting out a statement calling for an investigation into the origins of COVID that would be led by the World Health Organization. That's the same group that covered up for the communist regime when the pandemic first started. And President Biden still not ready to reveal whether he thinks it could come from a lab, while Mike Pompeo says the evidence is overwhelming.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: We haven't had access to the laboratories to determine whether or not -- and I haven't reached a conclusion because our intelligence community is not certain yet whether or not this was a consequence of a, from the market place of a bat or whether it was an experiment gone awry in a laboratory.

utterances.speaker: MIKE POMPEO, FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.utterance: There is an enormous amount of evidence that there was a leak from the Wuhan Institute of Virology, there's a pile of evidence 100 feet high.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Dagen, I don't think we are ever going to find out the origins, China is never going to let an unbiased team of scientists come into China and start looking all around, they are never going to allow it, so what's the point?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: What is the point? You know what, is it too much to ask for these leaders to just get angry?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: To just get mad. Instead they issue this watery, if not sugary statement --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- about a phase two probe, a second probe, by the World Health Organization in their first report got access to no data from China and then suggested that it was more likely, communist propaganda, by the way, more likely that the Wuhan virus was imported into China in frozen food, that was a more likely source than the Wuhan lab. And China is sitting back watching these numbskulls laughing, it's this boondoggle at the beach with the photo op seaside and then what did Boris Johnson say on Friday talking about we must build back in a greener, more gender-neutral, perhaps more feminine way. Meantime, four million, almost four million people are dead around the globe and China was the only economy growing last year. They are toothless, all of them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Dagen was referencing the photo op, Richard, where all the vaccinated leaders were doing a little elbow bump. I don't know what that was about. But address the point that the Chinese are not going to let people that are not handpicked into their country to look around, so what are we actually going to do? What would Richard Fowler do, leader of the free world, to really confront China and get to the bottom of the situation?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Thank you for giving me title leader of the free world, I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Number one, if I were the leader of the free world the first thing I would do is not have --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kill Jesse.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, I might keep Jesse around. You've got to have some help. You know, team of rivals.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Keep me around, Keep me around.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I got to keep him -- I might put him in the cabinet. But I don't think I would have the World Health Organization investigate this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I would probably have somebody else do it, maybe the IAEA, somebody who has some more credibility when it comes to investigating things in authoritarian countries, number one. But number two, where I will give the G7 credit it was the beachy picture, but remember, at last year's G7 they didn't even mention the word China in their communique, neither in the year before or the year before that. So the fact that the G7 which is a group of people that I really don't like to offend anybody decided that they were going to offend China by saying, hey, you have human rights violations, we think that you guys might have sort of, there's a possibility that there was a lab leak here so you guys spread COVID to the world so you guys are bad actors. I think that's a big step in the right direction for a group of people that don't like taking big steps.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What did you see come out of this G7, Dana? Was there anything concrete besides this little wishy-washy?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I wrote down, they had the statement, we will continue to consult, which is so pathetic I can't believe they felt the need to actually have to write it down and issue it to the world that they are going to -- well that's of course you are, that's the G7.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that's in -- that was in reference to the Wuhan lab leak possibility, so it came out of it. So, you have this build back better world, B3W, I think it's called, and this was the idea that finally G7 is going to try to take on China on its Belt and Road Initiative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is basically where China was just handing out contracts and money all around the world and basically taking everybody's resources from all around the world and actually not following through on anything that they promise. So, I talked to a friend recently had a good point, so we can either outsmart China, but we are not going to ever outspend them. So maybe this is perhaps a little bit of a concrete thing. I think it's kind of strange that it's built on Biden's campaign promise to America, the build back better, I don't know if that was a good idea for the G7. But other than that, it felt a little bit toothless, they also kept saying that they're so glad that they now have a president willing to cooperate. Part of what they mean by that is that willing to cooperate on the Iran nuclear deal --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- for example, the climate Paris accord, and then also this idea of, a trash idea that I will call the global minimum tax which is not necessarily going to happen but they agreed to look into it, and basically what that would do is screw America's tech companies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Greg, the president keeps been saying America is back. Well, back to getting manipulated by the Europeans?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Back to bending over, that's what it is. By the way, the summit was so boring that networks were forced to show old clips of like, remember Trump? Well, we hated him. This is really funny or Yeltsin dancing. The most interesting thing at the summit was Boris Johnson's hair which looked like a beach umbrella in a windstorm. It's just at any moment it could just fly off into space. Concerning these comments about China, I have coined a phrase, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like to hear it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The soft language of no expectations. That is a beautiful phrase which the media is already in the process of portraying as adults, isn't this adult, the idea of cooperation being adult. What we -- what I've always tried to push is that I would rather have my leader be like an agent or a lawyer that everybody hates so they don't expect cooperation and that they know it's going to be hard. I don't want them to have -- I don't want -- I want the freak show, you know? I don't want this -- I don't want this civilize photo op, to me that just looks like it's just another game. But Biden could start a war and the media would be like, at least he's not Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They are continuing to consult.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I will say, can I give one thing that I thought --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- was a positive was the agreement to try to help give vaccines to third world countries, that's positive. They can definitely --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And I think, Dana, to add to your point. The fact that they are doing this is also a counter way to the fact that Russia and China are giving out their vaccine, not as effective, but they're giving out their vaccine --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- with strings attached similar to many of the foreign direct investment road projects.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think we should have some strings attached to our vaccine.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because that's good diplomacy, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: That's not good diplomacy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's diplomacy. Vaccine diplomacy.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Anybody that's taking money from China for Belt and Road, let's just flood them with vaccines then they'll maybe come to our side. Ahead, President Biden promising to retaliate against cyber-attacks ahead of that big summit with Vladimir Putin.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER (on camera)
utterances.utterance: President Biden is getting ready to face off with Vladimir Putin after a series of cyber-attacks. The two leaders are going to meet face to face this Wednesday in a highly anticipated summit. Here's Biden's message ahead of the showdown.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I'm going to make clear to President Putin that there are areas where we can cooperate if he chooses and if he chooses not to cooperate and acts in a way that he has in the past relative to cybersecurity and some other activities, then we will respond. We will respond in kind.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER (on camera)
utterances.utterance: But Putin is already claiming he's not to blame for the hacks.

utterances.speaker: KEIR SIMMONS, SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT, NBC
utterances.utterance: Are you waging a cyber war against America?

utterances.speaker: VLADIMIR PUTIN, RUSSIAN PRESIDENT (through translator)
utterances.utterance: Where is the evidence? Where is proof? It's becoming farcical.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER (on camera)
utterances.utterance: So, Dana, you have helped a president prepare for one of these types of summits before.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: What's your take about what do you think is happening in the sort of Biden White House as they prepare for one of the biggest meetings of his presidency so far?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, a couple of different things. One, I think that right there in that interview you just saw, I believe Putin when he says where the evidence just like I believe the Chinese when they are like, there is no lab leak. I mean, I don't like -- I think that we just have to presume. Of course, we know where it's coming from. We know that he doesn't tell the truth. We know what he does to journalists in his own country. And he's down on this propaganda tour all around basically saying I am bigger and better than Biden. And I do seriously wonder why the White House called this a summit because a summit indicates that it's grand and it's big, where I said I think that they should've said, we are going to get coffee with Putin when we're over there in Brussels, that will be -- or in Geneva, we're going to stop by and have a couple -- cups of espresso and that's it. Because right now, what's different from when I was working for President Bush is that these attacks, these cyber-attacks are actually affecting normal people.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When you're talking about the money, when you're talking about like Colonial Pipeline, that's your gas. You're talking about meat, that's like our supply chain for how we actually feed ourselves, this summit or whatever they're going to call it is super important. The last thing I would say is, I think if you're going to have a summit, you have to have a press conference. If you are the leader of the free world then you have to have the other leader even if he is reluctant to stand next to you or maybe if you are concerned how you will look standing next to him, I still think that you have to do it in order to show that the media matters.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Fair point. Jesse, your take?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree with everything Dana said, he had a very, very shaky performance today during that press conference, they asked him, well you said Vlad is a killer, what gave you that impression and how do you negotiate with a killer? And he laughed like Kamala Harris and then he started to answer and then he paused for 10 seconds and then he restarted his answer was something completely unintelligible. I have no idea what he said, Richard, and that did not strike me as someone that's in command of the issues. They were asking what the goals are going into this meeting, he said he's not going to negotiate in front of the press but he did that yesterday. Putin floated the idea of the cyber- criminal swap and he said oh, yes, I'm open to it. And then the White House had to walk it bac. So, he seems confused to me. I don't think he's going to do well one on one with Vladimir Putin, he is going to probably do a lot of listening and he's probably going to be reading off a lot of script and then they are going to release a readout that says we challenged him here, they disagreed here, and the media is going to make him out to be Rambo. But that's not really the point. The point is you have to do something to Vladimir Putin to kind of snap him to attention and right now he hasn't done anything, he's let the pipeline go, he's trying to get back into the Iran nuke deal and he hasn't really -- he's basically surrendered on the cyber war. So, to Dana's point, almost every major summit you have with a Russian leader, you hold a joint news conference right afterwards. By holding a solo news conference that doesn't signal strength to me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That signals weakness to me. So, it's not like an arm-wrestling match, just go out there and answer questions.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: See, I mean, I want to push back on that a little bit because I think I've watched it. I think the White House is definitely setting lower expectations, they are setting the bar low so that they can come out with something high. But I think what's on the table for the Biden White House is the fact that Putin is sort of in a quagmire in Syria, right? He sort of, broke Syria and now he has to pay for it and guess what, he doesn't have any money, right? So, the United States is walking in with look, you want us to help you in Syria? We want all of these things in return. And you want to be this great leader that says you can prop up countries and you can't, and we're the only person that can help you here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's gotten a lot of money from Germany because that pipeline is going to go --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, but I think that's also benefiting the people of Germany, but that's another story for another day. Dagen?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They got plenty of money, and they're going to have more and greater control over the price of oil on the world stage. Because of Biden and company, we're backing away from our energy greatness. Look, you kill exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, but at the same time, Russneft in Russia is undertaking $170 billion oil and gas project that will produce enough oil to power -- to power the world for a year, roughly. So, we're handing power and riches to Putin. And secondly, I understand why you don't get on that stage and do a joint press conference because Biden is the classic weakling. You talk tough away from the great goon, but then you don't have the gumption to stand on the stage and say, hey, this guy is a killer. He's a malign actor. He's evil, and he uses KGB tactics and methods to destroy his enemies. He's an enemy of us. Biden would never do that. So, he looks like less of a coward not having to stand on the stage with Putin.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So, Greg, to Dana's point -- I mean, to Dagen's point there, I mean, no presidents would have gotten Putin right, right? Every president sort of battled with how do you battle this sort of 800-pound gorilla that is Vladimir Putin, right, and nobody's gotten to perfect. And how do you -- what --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I guess it's -- I think Trump kind of did because he understood that -- right now, what you're seeing is a strong man versus a straw man. And at least Trump under -- Trump dealt with people far worse than Putin contractors in Brooklyn. I mean, come on. I mean, the guy had to pull over and deal with mobsters, so I think he understands that mindset. And right now Joe seems shakier than at IKEA, you know, box-spring on a honeymoon. I think that what's missing in this whole thing is the America First-like card. And I think that's what Putin -- like, these people, that's all they understand because their country comes first. And so, I think when Trump is missing, and you have Biden there, it's more like what happened to the America first. And I think Putin use a very valid little strategy with the boy who cried wolf response when they were talking about what are you responsible? Of course, they're responsible for the -- for these hacks. But he's saying, look, you know, you guys are constantly accusing us of stuff, right? So, the Democrats and the media open that whole, you know, accusing the Russians of years and years of -- years of infiltrating our election system, which as you know is impossible. Our election system is unhackable and impervious. So, like, you know -- he's like, why do you go so -- you blame me for everything. Do you expect me to take this seriously? So, that was kind of the -- he was the boy who cried wolf on us, which was good. I'm rooting for Joe though as you know because I want him to do well. But I do think that Dana is correct. You know, it's a thing to get out of a date. You always say, why can't we have coffee? And then it's like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's never happened to you.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm rooting for Joe to and hopefully we can work together on securing our elections.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, me too. Up next, are the holidays offensive? Parents are revolting after the school board gets rid of them on its calendar.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: We hope you have a merry day off. Parents are calling for resignations after a school board in New Jersey voted to remove all holiday names from its academic calendar. The reason, to avoid hurting people's feelings. So, now federal holidays will be referred to as days off. Parents are fed up and saying the school board members need to step down.

utterances.speaker: TOM TATEM, PARENT, RANDOLPH SCHOOL DISTRICT
utterances.utterance: I think it's social media combined with political ideologies, and people that are in positions of, you know, perceived power are pushing their personal agendas instead of really doing what they're entrusted to do.

utterances.speaker: JAMES JACOBI, PARENT, RANDOLPH SCHOOL DISTRICT
utterances.utterance: This radical theme that we've seen for the last 12 months occur across the country is coming to your neighborhood soon.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Help, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think they've gone far enough. What are we going to do about the days of the week? Remember, they're named after planets, but the planets are named after gods, and all of them are men but one who is Venus who gave birth to Cupid who was responsible for creating a binary restrictive sexual fascism. You got Mars who's the god of war, that's actually Tuesday, so he's got to go. You could probably just go from Monday, which is the moon, to Wednesday. But Wednesday is mercury and Mercury is the god of finance, so that's evil. So, we got to change all those names. This hyper -- kind of hypersensitivity is being marshaled to tear down this country. And I know that sounds farfetched, but if you get really deep into it, it's about recreating America as oppressor versus oppressed, and it's -- and like, every revolution that is successful, it's being -- it's being controlled and created by a very tiny minority. It's a very small number of people who buy into this stuff. But that's all you need to scare the crap out of human resources, executives, politicians, and bureaucrats who are so frightened they will throw everybody under the bus thinking that they might not get hit.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: What's weird about this town and this county, Dana, I looked at the voter registrations, this is a Republican county. It is a Republican town that about three-quarters of the registered voters in this town are either Republican or like independent unaffiliated. It's a quarter Democrat. So, what it goes to is these people join the town council or join the school board because they want to lay on their nutso, wacko ideology on the whole town. And so, now, the parents are like, wait a minute, what the hell is going on here? And it could happen anywhere.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It only takes two people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It can. And the thing is that a lot of those people are good citizens. They probably vote in every election that they probably don't really pay too much attention as to who's going to be on the school board. This is happening all across America that all of a sudden, like, wait, this person ran for school board. Why shouldn't I run for school board? I think that people like the parents that we just saw are part of a new grassroots movement that is like the Tea Party. They just don't quite know it yet. And the reason why, as you think about ObamaCare, you might not have been able to say to like a person walking down the street, what is it -- what is it about ObamaCare and all the complexities that make you upset about? They just knew that it just didn't feel right. And that is what you're starting to see with critical race theory and other types of things like this with the school boards. People can't -- they can't exactly tell you exactly what's going on but they know that it's not the direction that they want to go. So, I do think you'll see a lot more parents at the school board meetings are possibly even running for office because the Democrats are now even being warned by their strategists. So, the third party people going oh, guys, maybe there's this a little bit too much here.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Richard, so the fight in this town started over Columbus Day. And instead, they turned around and canceled everything, including Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. That was -- that's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not going to upset.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Listen, I agree where it's -- I agree where this -- where it started. Now, where it's ended is something completely different. I do understand people who have problems with Columbus Day because I think there's a very clear reason to. Number one, Columbus wasn't the first European to touch on American shores, those are actually the Vikings, right? The Vikings saw the Indians and they had -- they sort of trade with them, but they didn't settle here. But we celebrate Columbus as sort of the first European --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We can argue that another day.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: We can. My point is that the indigenous -- that's a fair argument in a fair debate. Debating --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who introduced tobacco to us?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Fair, right? But I think, you know, the idea of getting rid of all the days on the calendar is not a good idea. But to your point, Dana, I do think that that, you know, there's certain things that over time people begin to like them. ObamaCare is one of those things. As people begin to -- as ObamaCare beginning to -- begin to be implemented, if you talk to folks in Kentucky, they love Kentucky Kynect which is ObamaCare in Kentucky, right, or the program in California -- what is it, Cal Health Care in California or the exchange in D.C. So, it's -- we have to get away from the labels and the talking points and actually what the policy actually is. In this particular case, this school board passed bad policy, and that's why we're talking about it on the show today.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: But this is the desired outcome for much of the left, to Greg's point.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's to create a communist-like sameness among everything.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They want to get -- this school board wants to get rid of Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But that's the school board. That's not the whole entire Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I lose five pounds right there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree with Richard. I think we should all get days off for Viking day. That was a good point. I just can't imagine the women in New Jersey getting the calendar in the mail and seeing the calendar and then tacking it up on the fridge and seeing the third Thursday of November be Thanksgiving, and just dropping their diet coke on the floor. No. New Jersey parents don't get offended. They offend other people. This is -- we're talking about New Jersey here, right? I was in New Jersey Home Goods the other day shopping and I had my cart piled high as heck, right? And I'm shopping, I'm shopping, all of a sudden I can't find my cart. And I'm looking around and I'm looking around. All of a sudden, all the items in my cart have been empty down on the couch and someone has stolen my shopping cart. These people don't get offended by Thanksgiving. These people are giving people black eyes on Black Friday. These are the kind of people that don't get offended. And you're right. You take away Martin Luther King Day, Black Americans are upset. Christmas, Christians are upset. They've offended more people by trying to be politically correct. We should change the name of the town. Did you know the town was founded by a wealthy landowner Hartshorne Fitz Randolph. He ran the Indians off their land.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then, Big Iron Mine used to make weapons for the Continental Army. Very violent, very aggressive, I say we call it blank New Jersey now.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Johnny is good.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm just mad that you got your cart was stolen at Home Goods.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: My car was stolen.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: It could be you just reaping what you sowed. But you know, hey --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe you stole -- maybe you stole your cart from somebody.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think, this is karma?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's cart-ma.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good one.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They didn't like what was in your cart and it needed to be replaced with more sensitive item.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, listen, whatever it is, I'm a victim.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And then you got stuck with no cart.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Victim, victim, victim shaming. Next, a diver claimed he was swallowed by a giant whale, but experts say, that's fishy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Experts are casting doubt on one man's Whale of a Tale. A lobster diver off Cape Cod claims a humpback whale swallowed him up and then spit him out.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL PACKARD, CLAIMS HE WAS SWALLOWED BY A WHALE
utterances.utterance: Everything went black. And then I realized after I said -- it's not a shark. The only other thing is I just got eaten by a whale.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Michael Packard says he was in the whale's mouth for 30 to 40 seconds and thought he might die. But then the creature launched him onto the surface of the ocean where his diving mate picked him up, and he only sustained badly bruised legs. And now, Packard wants Matt Damon to play him in a future movie about his encounter. Now, some people are questioning whether this has actually happened. I think that if you want people to believe you, you might wait on the Matt Damon story, about the Matt Damon part of the story. I was like, wait Jonah and the whale in the Bible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, so the dead giveaway that this is a lie is the Matt Damon thing because it's impossible. His head is too monstrous. It's like stonehedge. He's like to James Vanderbeeks. You know, James Vanderbeek's head is massive, but Matt Damon's head too, So, he picked -- there's no way that Matt Damon's head can fit in a whale. This man is lying. And you know what the penalty is for fishermen who lie about getting swallowed by whales? Execution.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, you believe him, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I feel like an idiot, Dana, enough for the usual reasons. I went all around this weekend telling people, hey, do you hear about the lobsterman swallowed by a whale? And now it's fake news.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's not exactly --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, now everyone is saying it could be fake and it hurt my credibility.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And so, now, I want believe him. I don't think we should be poking holes in this guy's story. This is a Whale of a Tale, or whatever you want to say, and it gives us hope.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What hope?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It had happened in history, right, Dagen?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It gives us hope that, you know, maybe crazy things do happen and we can talk about them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, it does happened.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: It happened in the Bible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In the Bible.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There are other stories --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The first time that Democrat cites the Bible.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Hey. I mean, I remember the -- I remember the childhood book we were just talking about during the break of Jonah in the whale and that happened. But this door right here, that didn't happen and. And Jesse, you know it didn't happen. Come on, man.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he has bruised legs, Dagen. How did he get the bruised legs?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And the Matt Damon was the dead giveaway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: All right, two things. This story is more believable than the Wuhan wet market story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think I agree.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And two, he picked Matt Damon because Matt Damon is from Massachusetts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And he's from Massachusetts. And we know that people trying to do a Massachusetts Hollywood accent are even worse at it than people do in Southern Hollywood accent. Even Matt Damon's Massachusetts accent is bad, but it's not going to be like George Clooney, Diane Lane bad from the Perfect Storm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would tell you, I totally believe it. And Michael Packard didn't have --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't believe the Perfect Storm story. I don't understand the Perfect Storm because how did he get that whole story if nobody came back? Am I right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't even know what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wait, I don't know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not the book. I'm talking about the movie.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So, a perfect question. So, if this really happened, where was the witness, like, the other diver mate that saw it? Why is he not out here?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think he has been out and about. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did somebody come --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm a little busy this morning.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did somebody come back on the Perfect Storm? Fact-check me on that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fact-check.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If somebody came back, then I'm wrong.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But is that true?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for "ONE MORE THING." Get the table. Let's do this. That's perverse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Animals are great. Animals are great. Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just like old times. You know, some animals are great because they're just like humans, like the little baby, two-toed sloth seen here getting fed. Just born at the Brevard Zoo in Florida. Fun fact, Dana. The baby two-toed sloth has an I.Q. of 180.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. 180 and can already drive a motorcycle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very slowly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what, I just didn't feel like doing a two-toed sloths fact so I thought I would make them up. Anyway, look at those little eyeballs, little drum.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You really want one?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I do want one. I want it. Yes, I'll take one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know, the lobstermen also swallowed by the sloth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Two animals in one weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Crazy weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's happened to me. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right,Â congratulationsÂ to Greg and Ashley, my brother and sister-in-law. They just had a baby boy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is right. On June 6, 5:52 p.m., Gregory James was born weighing eight pounds, four ounces, bigger than Jesse Jr. I'm not competitive about it, not at all.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What's the name of the baby?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Gregory James. And he's adorable. And now Jesse Jr. is going to have a cousin to get into trouble with for the rest of his life. Speaking of getting into trouble, I forgot to plug my book during a speech I made in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania to the Pennsylvania Leadership Council, and so I'm going to plug it right now. Go buy my book. It's pre-ordered available right now. The hard copy just came in. Greg has already read it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's 300 pages. He didn't prepare for the show at all. He just read my book.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It took 10 minutes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very, very interested in what he read. And you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no index. How can I find my name?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We didn't want an index, you know, for legal reasons. They don't want it easily, you know, searchable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, some thanks for naming the kid after me. I mean, come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We might have to change the birth certificate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I have a little animal video. So, my friends down in South Carolina --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hope this is a new one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- they have dogs -- yes, it's a new one. My friends Grady and Bentley down in South Carolina, they don't have a pool because they can't get a pool. But this dog shows them how it's done. He just figured -- you just make your own pool. Make your own fun right there. He loves the water, bath time, playtime.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what they did it slip and slide. They made their own pool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thankfully, this is not the slip and slide. And I I know people can find out more about that on "GUTFELD!"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. We're going to have a big expose on the explosive diarrhea that occurred at slip and slide tonight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, it was not this morning.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Dagen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can't wait to see the numbers on that.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I love -- I love that you came to me with that introduction. I do know a lot about E. coli in waterparks. You should have me on your show. I'll be your special correspondent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. You'll have its poop.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The scoop on the poop. Sorry. I'm not participating it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: So, what is faster than an Indy car? This squirrel. This was at the Detroit Grand Prix. Watch it. Watch it. That's Ryan Hunter-Reay. Wait, no, watch him. He's alive. And he scurries off because that squirrel is a badass.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it took a lot of nuts.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, it did. Boom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can you beat that, Richard?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I can. Speaking about badasses, the Ticker Tape Parade is coming back to New York. And this time, it's an honor of all the doctors, nurses, and healthcare heroes, total badasses. And there'll be on July 7. And yes, there'll be a Ticker Tape Parade right here in New York City in the Big Apple.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, how can the environmentalists allow that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, are we included? Aren't we the real heroes? We're the frontline -- we're the real frontline. The talk show hosts are the front row heroes? I mean, it's going to be the doctor and the fireman, but come on, what am I doing every day?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Doctors, nurses, respiratory therapists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm in between the doctors and the nurses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They say --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So, before the respiratory therapist?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I saved the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you saved the world. All right, I was joking by the way. That's it for us. "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hello, Bret.
